title: How to Clean Stamped Concrete

steps.headline: Sweep the surface.
steps.description: The first step in cleaning a stamped concrete surface is removing loose dirt and grime from the surface. Use a broom to remove loose debris from the concrete. If it is an outdoor surface, you can use a leaf blower for extra assistance.

steps.headline: Wet mop the surface.
steps.description: For regular cleaning of stamped concrete surfaces, a weekly wet mopping is usually sufficient. After sweeping the floor, dip a rope or foam mop into a bucket of warm water. Thoroughly mop the floor, rinsing the mop regularly. Make sure you change the mopping water when it becomes dirty.

steps.headline: Try mild detergent.
steps.description: If water is not enough to clean your stamped concrete surface, you can add a nonabrasive cleanser to your mopping water. A few drops of dish soap, laundry detergent, or other mild detergent is usually enough to create an effective cleaning solution. Avoid chemical-based cleaners as these can dull the surface.

steps.headline: Consider pressure washing outdoor surfaces.
steps.description: If water and mild detergent are not effective, you can use a pressure washer to remove tough stains from a stamped concrete surface. Pressure washing can help remove tire marks, leaf stains, and grease spots. Try renting a pressure washer at your local hardware store.

steps.headline: Try using an alkaline degreaser to remove oil, grease, or soot.
steps.description: An alkaline degreaser can help lift stains like oil and grease to the surface of stamped concrete. Use the degreaser with hot water. Make sure you follow all directions on the degreaser label.

steps.headline: Use oxalic acid to remove rust.
steps.description: If your stamped concrete has a rust stain, you might be able to remove it using a cleaner with oxalic acid. Make sure you consult the company that installed or manufactured your stamped concrete before deciding to use oxalic acid.

steps.headline: Sweep or dry dust mop the surface weekly.
steps.description: Once you clean a stamped concrete surface, it is important to keep it free from dirt, leaves, and other debris that might scratch the surface. Use a broom, leaf blower, or garden hose to remove debris weekly.

steps.headline: Reseal the surface every 2-3 years.
steps.description: A sealer will protect the color and sheen of your stamped concrete surface. Apply sealer to stamped concrete surfaces every 2-3 years to help block penetrating dirt, dust, and stains and protect against wear and abrasion. Talk to the contractor that initially installed the stamped concrete to find out what sealer is best for your surface.

steps.headline: Consider polishing high traffic areas.
steps.description: If you have high traffic indoor areas, you might see signs of wear on your stamped concrete surface. If this is the case, consider using a floor polish or wax on the surface for extra protection. Make sure the polish is formulated for stamped concrete.

steps.headline: Avoid deicing salts and chemicals.
steps.description: Your stamped concrete surface will last longer if you avoid using harsh agents to remove snow and ice, such as salts or chemicals. These substances can dull or crack the stamped concrete surface over time.

text: Doing a General Cleaning Sweep the surface. The first step in cleaning a stamped concrete surface is removing loose dirt and grime from the surface. Use a broom to remove loose debris from the concrete. If it is an outdoor surface, you can use a leaf blower for extra assistance. Wet mop the surface. For regular cleaning of stamped concrete surfaces, a weekly wet mopping is usually sufficient. After sweeping the floor, dip a rope or foam mop into a bucket of warm water. Thoroughly mop the floor, rinsing the mop regularly. Make sure you change the mopping water when it becomes dirty. Try mild detergent. If water is not enough to clean your stamped concrete surface, you can add a nonabrasive cleanser to your mopping water. A few drops of dish soap, laundry detergent, or other mild detergent is usually enough to create an effective cleaning solution. Avoid chemical-based cleaners as these can dull the surface. Addressing Tough Stains Consider pressure washing outdoor surfaces. If water and mild detergent are not effective, you can use a pressure washer to remove tough stains from a stamped concrete surface. Pressure washing can help remove tire marks, leaf stains, and grease spots. Try renting a pressure washer at your local hardware store. Try using an alkaline degreaser to remove oil, grease, or soot. An alkaline degreaser can help lift stains like oil and grease to the surface of stamped concrete. Use the degreaser with hot water. Make sure you follow all directions on the degreaser label. Use oxalic acid to remove rust. If your stamped concrete has a rust stain, you might be able to remove it using a cleaner with oxalic acid. Make sure you consult the company that installed or manufactured your stamped concrete before deciding to use oxalic acid. Maintaining a Stamped Concrete Surface Sweep or dry dust mop the surface weekly. Once you clean a stamped concrete surface, it is important to keep it free from dirt, leaves, and other debris that might scratch the surface. Use a broom, leaf blower, or garden hose to remove debris weekly. Reseal the surface every 2-3 years. A sealer will protect the color and sheen of your stamped concrete surface. Apply sealer to stamped concrete surfaces every 2-3 years to help block penetrating dirt, dust, and stains and protect against wear and abrasion. Talk to the contractor that initially installed the stamped concrete to find out what sealer is best for your surface. Consider polishing high traffic areas. If you have high traffic indoor areas, you might see signs of wear on your stamped concrete surface. If this is the case, consider using a floor polish or wax on the surface for extra protection. Make sure the polish is formulated for stamped concrete. Avoid deicing salts and chemicals. Your stamped concrete surface will last longer if you avoid using harsh agents to remove snow and ice, such as salts or chemicals. These substances can dull or crack the stamped concrete surface over time.
